reviewText: Before Valve crossovers were mere fodder for pre-purchase exclusives and newly released PC ports on Steam, Peggle Extreme dared to dream, by offering Orange Box customers a unique journey into a world where Peggle, Half-Life and Team Fortress collide for no apparent reason, creating a unique story where cute animals from Peggle rebel against the extra-dimensional invaders of the Valve multiverse (here portrayed as far more genocidal than Valve would have liked). In fact, it's the same MacGyver-esque plot device that Valve resorted to when they created the Perpetual Testing Initiative story for Portal 2. Mere coincidence????\n\n... Okay, setting aside the fanman sarcasm, Peggle Extreme is really fun, mildly replayable, and worth trying if you're ever... bored, I suppose. Give it a try!

reviewText: I like this witty exploit of classic arcanoid principles bringing fresh feeling to it. I adore its foolish presentation as a goofy looking unicorn askes you to save his planet from space monsters. Also it's got nice balance between player skill and pure physics based luck. Everyone should try it for it is free and provides some pleasant relaxation.\n\nМне нравится эта эксплуатация классических принципов арканоида с новыми ощущениями. Радует дурацкое введение в игру, когда единорог с глупым лицом просит спасти его планету от космических чудовищ. Также здесь хороший баланс между навыками игрока и чистой удачей, основанной на физике. Каждому следует попробовать, так как игра бесплатна и дает возможность приятно расслабиться.

reviewText:
5min of peggle extreme
https://youtu.be/0H1S7tJdLWM

This is a take on pachinko an Asian gambling game but in here your just trying to hit all the orange blocks.
This game has 2 parts with 5 levels each = 10 boards for counter-strike, portal, & team fortress 2.
Each character has a special power that activates when you hit a green block but in here you can Only play as the blue unicorn with the guide power that shows where the ball next bounce will go.
Pink blocks boost your points that will fill a bar each time you release the ball and you'll get a extra every time you fill it but it resets on each launch.
There is also a basket on the bottom that moves back and forth and if you can get the ball in here you won't lose it.
The game end when all orange blocks are hit or you lose all your balls.

Peggle Extreme is a variant of Peggle (Deluxe) from Popcap Games. It was offered with the Orange Box and it's not really a surprise: Popcap Games is also using Steam (mandatory when playing the Orange Box on PC) for broadcasting games made by them.

The story of Peggle Extreme is simple: you have to defend the Peggle Institute from invaders during 10 levels. Let me explain the gameplay. You have peggles on your screen. Peggles are these points or rectangles with different colors. Blue ones are the basic peggle, the orange ones are the ones you have to eliminate, the green ones are the speciality from your guide (in PE, it's only Bjorn the Unicorn and the fact that he can show the trajectory of your ball) and the rose one are point boosts and are chosen randomly when launching a new ball. The goal is to launch a ball and eliminate a maximum of peggles. I mean, with ten balls, you've had to eliminate every orange peggle, others being point bonuses. You have a bucket moving at the bottom and you can earn a free ball if the one currently launched falls into it.

You can also earn free balls by reaching a certain score with one ball during its play. The first step is 25.000 points. Also, you have the fevermeter. When reaching the X2, X3, etc., it increases the points tied to peggles: for example, a blue one that brings 10 points when touched is bringing 20 points when touched when your fevermeter indicates X2. And it's valid during all the level. There are also special bonuses like the long shot (touching two peegles far away from each other) or the lucky bounce (the ball touches the bucket, is bouncing and then falls into it. If it don't fall into it, the lucky bounce is missed). If your ball falls into the void without touching a peggle, you will have a coin with Free Ball or No Ball appearing. It's randomly, so, you can only pray that you'll have a second chance. That's only a view of the bonuses existing (you have extreme slide, orange attack, etc..). When finishing a level, the bucket disappeared and five special bonuses appear: 10.000 at the far left and far right, 50.000 for the two others and for the middle, it's 100.000 points. Note that if you clean your screen of all the peggles, you're unlocking Ultra Extreme Fever and all the five voids bring 100.000 points.

You have also special features for the duel mode: -25% of your points if the ball doesn't touch a peggle and falls directly in the void or in the bucket for example.

The backgrounds are customized to the Orange Box games with Peggle Masters appearing in it. Half-Life 2 Episode 2 is represented by a Vortigaunt attacking a Peggle Master, a Headcrab, a Hunter. Team Fortress is symbolized by an Heavy with a Peggle Master, a sentry build by an Engineer, a Pyro pursuing a Peggle Master and a BOOM! probably taken from a trailer. Portal is more interesting by the fact that you have portals that change the location of your ball. You have the lovely turret and the Weighed Companion Cube. Every game is featuring the voice of characters appearing in it. For HL2E2, it didn't really let a trace in my brain but for TF2, you have the voice from the Heavy, like the You did well!". For Portal
date: it's our dear psycho Glados.\n\nAs you can suppose
hoursPlayed: not really complicated and very cartoonish for the Peggle Masters. Backgrounds are more similar to the original graphics of the game than being cartooned. Soundtrack is also perfect.\n\nThe different modes are also challenging. Duel Mode is made for playing alone against the computer or for playing with a friend. Adventure Mode is the solo campaign. The Quick Mission is for playing unlocked levels and the Challenge Mode is for people liking Challenge. It's a sort of Bonus Map like in Portal: you have to beat the challenge for gaining the title of Peggle Master for the level: clean all the peggles
voteText: reach a certain high score: 300.000 for example
helpfulPercent: eliminate all the orange peggles (the classic gameplay). I can guarantee you that reaching a high score is easier than trying to clean your screen. Currently
votesHelpful: I'm a Peggle Master in each level
votesTotal: the last title is the cleaning of the first level with the Vort.\n\nPeggle Extreme isn't suffering from flaws
votesFunny: apart the shortness of the game
commentsCount: being a product designed for the Orange Box and the fact that you will not beat every level at your first try. Believe me
column16: you'll find the BOOM! and the sentry levels very challenging. And wait to see the level from Portal and its three parts you can only access by taking portals.\n\nAnyway
column20: you don't know what you're missing. I mean
column21: if you can afford the Orange Box or if you can buy on Steam. Peggle Extreme is probably one of the best casual games I've played and I'll admit it: seeing G-Man as the sun or Bjorn with a Headcrab is something that HL fans can't miss. Anyway

reviewText: Fun as hell.

Shortened version of Peggle with Orange Box theme
This game is a shortened version of Peggle Deluxe to introduce and bring players to the game
It's free and has Orange Box themed backgrounds which the levels are designed around
It has a short campaign of 10 levels and 5 Master challenges

9/10- Good game to just relax and play on the side, pretty short unless you want to do all the 100% cleared levels

Product received for free\n\nIf you like puzzle games, Peggle is here for you. It's for a casual audience. Not too hard. Not too easy. This game is charming and has replayability. This game reminds me of pachinko or bagatelle. Colorful balls, using special powers, and using brain power. Check out the game. Peggle Extreme is free and it's also a quick download.
The Best of Valve in a Peggle game. I like that. Sadly, you only play as Bjorn in this edition of Peggle. I wanna find a way to play as other masters, like my bro, Jimmy Lightning.

Summary: Highly addictive puzzler arcade game. Well worth checking out, the premise seems boring - normally I wouldn't even bother with these games. However this game is mega fun - Download it!

Graphics: Nothing exciting in this department, but they absolutely sufficient for the game and been well designed to match it's style.
Sound: They get stuck in your head....they get you addicted, it's like a drug.
Gameplay: Very fun, combined with the game parlour sounds that go off everytime a ball is knocking against a peg...devilishly addictive :)

reviewText:
Peggle Extreme is a puzzle game but it is not a full game – it is only 10 levels long. It has the normal single player mode as well as several variant gameplay modes for the same levels, including Duel, Challenge and Quick Play.
The levels are inspired by Half-Life 2, Team Fortress 2 and Portal.
The gameplay is really simple, you shoot balls down into a board of pegs with the goal of hitting certain pegs to clear the level.
The game is really short, it is easily beaten in well under half an hour, and it's replay value is very limited.
Peggle Extreme is free and it is entertaining for the first twenty minutes but not for much longer.

Sounds 6/10
Graphics 4/10
Gameplay 5/10
Atmosphere 6/10

If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:

reviewText:
It didnt even take an hour to complete the Story Mode, but this is a F2P game and i played it a lot in World of Warcraft as addon, had some great fishing trips with this game ^^

Extremely fun little time taking ball point shooter game, but i would mostly recommend this if you are bored or tired or on your way to bed, but still just in the mood to play something relaxing and chilling, well then Peggle Extreme is for you =)

You can also purchase the 2 full games, Peggle Deluxe and Peggle Nights if you really enjoy this little most enjoyable ball shooting game =)

This game is somewhat like Plinko mixed with Bubble shooter and is actually very ebtertaining gameplay-wise. I also think its kinda neat how they put all of the valve games into it, altough this did lead me to a lot of confusion because you get things like headcrabs turning unicorns into zombies in what would otherwise be a kids game

3/5 Stars\nThe concept is cool cause I like bizarre mash-ups ,but I imagined it would be a cartoony mash up. I assumed that it would be something like Glados mocking you, or the unicorn staring at a head crab. But instead I saw background with the Peggle Masters being set on fire! You'd imagine my surprise at the title screen! I actually got scared. I thought you would be able to play as Glados on a Portal themed level, maybe even the offer of cake. But, I seriously can't look past that title screen. Was the gore really necessary? Couldn't you have  the unicorn stand next to a companion cube or the characters be allies rather than intruders. The gameplay is the same as Paggle with the only change being the backgrounds and using Portals for 2 or 3 levels. Anyway, it's worth a try just expect SOME surprises and not an actual team up. More like a cameo apperance. Anyway, thats my 2 cents

Peggle is one of PopCap's most addictive games - and that's saying something considering most of the developer's catalog is basically crack in digital form.  Not helping matters is this free ten-level version, Peggle Extreme, released in 2007 to promote both Peggle and The Orange Box.  Previously, only people who purchased The Orange Box had access to Extreme, but now this darkly hilarious crossover on the happy-go-lucky world of Peggle is free for everyone.

And if that's not enough for you, they also made a free version of Peggle to promote World of Warcraft (specifically, Wrath of the Lich King).  Get it here:
http://www.popcap.com/promos/pegglewow/

Did I mention they're both free?

Ever wondered what Peggle would be like as an action game? Now's your chance.

For those who don't know, Peggle is an arcade-style game, by PopCap Games, in which the player shoots balls at pegs littering the screen, the goal being to hit all the orange pegs. It's a very easy-going game, with simple graphics and music. Which is why it's surprising that Peggle Extreme exists.

Peggle Extreme takes the classic Peggle gameplay and juxtaposes it with imagery and sounds from Valve's The Orange Box. It's kinda weird to see such a laid-back game crossing over with the likes of Half-Life 2, Team Fortress 2, and Portal, especially since the music is the same easy-listening cheese found in the original Peggle. But the gameplay remains intact, and it's well worth downloading, since you don't have to pay for it.

It only comes with 10 levels and one instructor (Bjorn the unicorn), but there are also five challenges that you can try out. It's a pretty short game, but if you're already a fan, or you've never played any game in the series, this is a great little spin-off to get, especially for free.

This is a very cool cross-over game of Popcap's 'Peggle' and Valve's 'Portal', 'Team Fortress 2', and 'Half-life'. In a way it is like a demo, with only 10 levels and 5 challenges to complete. On the other hand, a demo features gameplay from the actual game, whereas 'Peggle Extreme' features never-before-seen gameplay, not seen in the original 'Peggle'. Keep in mind, of course, that this game, 'Peggle Extreme' is free so you won't pay a cent, but with so little amount of gameplay, you can be done in possibly  around 1 hr 30 min, and the only way to get more gameplay is to buy Peggle (which I also recommend, if you like this game). Even though, at some points, it feels like a giant advertisement to the original game 'Peggle', you can still get free entertainment with content that isn't in Peggle, and the cross-over with Valve is very interesting.

Peggle is one of PopCap's most addictive games - and that's saying something considering most of the developer's catalog is basically crack in digital form.  Not helping matters is this free ten-level version, Peggle Extreme, released in 2007 to promote both Peggle and The Orange Box.  Previously, only people who purchased The Orange Box had access to Extreme, but now this darkly hilarious crossover on the happy-go-lucky world of Peggle is free for everyone.

And if that's not enough for you, they also made a free version of Peggle to promote World of Warcraft (specifically, Wrath of the Lich King).  Get it here:
http://www.popcap.com/promos/pegglewow/

Did I mention they're both free?
Chee Chee Peggle Fever!

Peggle is one of those shareware games that were quite a big thing few years ago, with wacky likeable graphic and simple gameplay, all to fit for the tastes of the wide audience of casual gamers (For example, your mom). And Peggle Extreme goes even more wacky, being a free promotional demo-version with levels taking place in universe of Valve's Orange Box games, with unicorn being the only available character. (who has his head being eaten by headcrab at title screen, scaring some part of casual audience away)

It's a completely free single player game that includes 10 exclusive levels, as been said, as well as hard 5 challenge levels for people who mastered peggle gameplay, as well as duel, with local multiplayer, where players take turns in shooting ball out. Nope, no Internet multiplayer there.

It should give you a good taste at what Peggle games are about. The gameplay was inspired by Pachinko games and been made just a bit more skill-based, while still having to guess where the ball will ricochet off. You take control of the cannon on top of screen and shoot uncontrollable ball in direction you choose, after which you are left hoping to get lucky to hit more orange pegs than just one.  You still can try to measure the timing, to get lucky to have your ball fall into basket, giving it back for free, or get one more ball by scoring a as many pegs and bonuses as possible. Out of all the pegs, orange ones, that are randomly chosen each time, are the only ones that you are required to hit to beat the level.

Graphics are random simple 2D cuteness and just randomness, and music is forgetable, aside from use of classic here and there.

Also, I don't think that it uses any of Steam features, I couldn't even bring up the Steam Overlay. Good thing this game is alt+tab friendly.

Personally, I think that this game is too much based on luck/guessing/measuring-like-a-robot, but since it's free, you should try it and decide for yourself.

reviewText: An Orange Box inspired demo for the insanely addictive Peggle? Yes and Please!
Like Peggle, but free, Valve-themed and short.
STUPID GAME BLOOD IN GAME AND THIS SUPPOSED TO BE AN FRIENDLY GAME!\n\n

This is one of the few games that my Mother and I play and enjoy together.  The only other game that she enjoys playing is Tetris (of course, because all moms enjoy playing Tetris...it's the law).  XD,

Peggle is one of those shareware games that were quite a big thing few years ago, with wacky likeable graphic and simple gameplay, all to fit for the tastes of the wide audience of casual gamers (For example, your mom). And Peggle Extreme goes even more wacky, being a free promotional demo-version with levels taking place in universe of Valve's Orange Box games, with unicorn being the only available character. (who has his head being eaten by headcrab at title screen, scaring some part of casual audience away)

It's a completely free single player game that includes 10 exclusive levels, as been said, as well as hard 5 challenge levels for people who mastered peggle gameplay, as well as duel, with local multiplayer, where players take turns in shooting ball out. Nope, no Internet multiplayer there.

It should give you a good taste at what Peggle games are about. The gameplay was inspired by Pachinko games and been made just a bit more skill-based, while still having to guess where the ball will ricochet off. You take control of the cannon on top of screen and shoot uncontrollable ball in direction you choose, after which you are left hoping to get lucky to hit more orange pegs than just one.  You still can try to measure the timing, to get lucky to have your ball fall into basket, giving it back for free, or get one more ball by scoring a as many pegs and bonuses as possible. Out of all the pegs, orange ones, that are randomly chosen each time, are the only ones that you are required to hit to beat the level.

Graphics are random simple 2D cuteness and just randomness, and music is forgetable, aside from use of classic here and there.

Also, I don't think that it uses any of Steam features, I couldn't even bring up the Steam Overlay. Good thing this game is alt+tab friendly.

Personally, I think that this game is too much based on luck/guessing/measuring-like-a-robot, but since it's free, you should try it and decide for yourself.
Addictive! That is all?

This game basically is a playable demo of the unique game Peggle. I own both Peggle 1 and Peggle 2 on Xbox 360. While Peggle 2 had new characters, Peggle 1 had more characters.

This review is basically just to say if you enjoy Peggle Extreme, I'd recommend grabbing the free demo of Peggle Deluxe and if you like that getting Peggle Complete for $8.99 (what it costs at the time of this review).

The easiest way to sum this game up is that you shoot a ball from a cannon on top of the level down towards pegs. If you can eliminate all the orange pegs before you run out of remaining balls, you'll win the stage. You can also land your balls into a bucket to receive your ball for that turn back at least in single player anyway.

This game takes precision to get high scores but it gets really fun as you get more used to it.

This game basically is a playable demo of the unique game Peggle. I own both Peggle 1 and Peggle 2 on Xbox 360. While Peggle 2 had new characters, Peggle 1 had more characters.

This review is basically just to say if you enjoy Peggle Extreme, I'd recommend grabbing the free demo of Peggle Deluxe and if you like that getting Peggle Complete for $8.99 (what it costs at the time of this review).

The easiest way to sum this game up is that you shoot a ball from a cannon on top of the level down towards pegs. If you can eliminate all the orange pegs before you run out of remaining balls, you'll win the stage. You can also land your balls into a bucket to receive your ball for that turn back at least in single player anyway.

This game takes precision to get high scores but it gets really fun as you get more used to it.

Product received for free

A great game for a little distraction.
Peggle Extreme was an early Steam release that saw the original Peggle gameplay reskinned for Valve characters and themes from the newly-released Orange Box. This version does not hold as many levels as Peggle Deluxe offers but the replayability more than makes up for it. This is a game that can easily be played for a few minutes on the backburner while other tasks take the forefront of your attention. The graphical options are substandard, while the control in gameplay is top-notch. Overall, this is a worthy addition to anyone's library if you're looking for a game to take your attention for a bit.

This was a really fun little demo for Peggie, which is one of my favorite puzzle games, with a Valve skin, the levels feature the games in The Orange Box (those being Team Fortress 2, Half-life 2 and its episodes, and Portal) and its just real good fun, if you want to try out Peggle before buying the full game or you're a Peggle master and you want your quick fix of Peggle but tired of playing the same levels over and over again, then Peggle Extreme is for you

Mean Mr. Mustard's short Peggle Extreme review

1) Essential - buy it NOW
2) Recommended - buy it on sale 3) Avoid

Time to complete – 63 minutes
Played multiplayer? N/A
Worth revisiting? No, the original Peggle is a better package

Best part – Retains that addictive Peggle gameplay but mixes it with Valve characters and themes
Worst part – Really short, more a Peggle demo than a fully fledged game, hence why it's free
It's like a Peggle demo but with Orange Box stuff. And it's free! How can you go wrong with that combination?
